newsitem.title: Japan: Softbank taking 35 percent stake in U.S. software firm.
newsitem.headline: Softbank taking 35 percent stake in U.S. software firm.

text.p: Japan's Softbank Corp., the world's largest computer magazine and book publisher, said Monday it will take a 35 percent stake in California anti-virus software firm TrendMicro for 3.5 billion yen ($31 million).
The company said payment to TrendMicro would be made by Dec. 27.
"In order to expand business, our group will strive to back up TrendMicro's Internet-related business," Softbank President Masayoshi Son told a news conference.

Softbank will try to persuade some 50 computer hardware makers worldwide to use Cupertino, Calif.-based TrendMicro's software in their systems and ask other makers to integrate the software in their memory boards, he said.
Son said his company will continue to actively invest in Internet-related businesses but not necessarily with any large-scale purchases.
Softbank plans to use part of the money to be raised through a new share issue to finance its investment in TrendMicro. Softbank is traded over-the-counter in Tokyo.
A Softbank source said that TrendMicro has already moved its headquarters to Tokyo as part of its plan to list its shares on Japan's over-the-counter market as early as 1998.
Softbank has become the world's largest computer-related magazine and book publisher through a string of buyouts.
In the summer, it also launched a joint digital satellite television service, known as J-SkyB, with Australian media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's News Corp.
In June, the two bought 21.4 percent of national television network Asahi National Broadcasting of Japan.
